p: A phytochemical study of hydroethanolic extracts from E. giganteum (L.) showed the presence of flavonoid derivates (mainly quercetin and kaempferol) and presented significant anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and antiproliferative activities [ 11]. Similarly, an analysis of aqueous extracts from E. myriochaetum showed the presence of flavonoid derivatives, such as kaempferol-3- O-sophoroside, kaempferol-3,7-di- O-β-glucoside, kaempferol-3- O-sophoroside-4’- O-β-glucoside, and caffeoylmethylate-4-β-glucopyranoside [ 12]. Aqueous and butanoic extracts from E. myriochaetum did not show a genotoxic effect, but did, however, show a hypoglycemic effect in patients with type 2 diabetes after 90 min of application [ 13].
